isis.stitle: 13 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS EATON RTLO-14613 - AIR SYSTEM - SPLITTER SHIFT AIR SYSTEM

svcsubproc.title: TROUBLESHOOTING
svcsubproc.para: If the transmission fails to shift or shifts too slowly to or from the "split" position, the fault may be in the Splitter Shift Air System or related components of the Range Shift Air System.
To locate the trouble, the following checks should be made with normal vehicle air pressure supplied to the system, but with the engine off.

warning.para: NEVER WORK UNDER A VEHICLE WHILE ENGINE IS RUNNING as personal injury may result from the sudden and unintended movement of vehicle under power. Always place transmission in the neutral position.

note.para: It is assumed that correct PSl readings were obtained from the air filter/regulator and all air lines have been checked for leaks.

step1.para: Air Supply. With the gear shift lever in neutral, select HIGH or LOW RANGE and loosen the connection at the "S" Port of the Roadranger Valve until it can be determined that AIR is supplied to valve. Reconnect air line.
If there is NO AIR, check for a restriction in the air line between the Roadranger valve and slave valve. Make sure this line is connected to the fitting at the Supply Port of the slave valve.

Roadranger Valve. With the gear shift lever in neutral, disconnect the air line at the Left Port of the splitter cylinder cover, making sure this line leads from the "SP" Port of the Roadranger Valve.

step2.para: WHILE IN HIGH or LOW RANGE, move the Splitter Control Button FORWARD. There should be AIR flowing from the disconnected line. Move the button REARWARD to shut off air flow and reconnect the air line.
If the preceding conditions did not exist, the Roadranger valve is defective, or there is a restriction in the air lines.

step1.para: Splitter Cylinder ( Figure 8). If any of the seals in the splitter cylinder assembly are defective, the splitter shift will be affected. The degree of air lost will govern the degree of failure, from slow shifting to complete shift failure.

step2.para: Leak at O-ring A results in a slow shift to engage rear auxiliary drive gear; pressurizing of transmission case; auxiliary gearing can be disengaged.

Leak at O-ring B results in slow shifting or complete failure to engage and disengage front or rear auxiliary drive gearing; steady flow of air from exhaust port of Roadranger valve and/or cylinder cover when Splitter Control Button is in the REARWARD position.
Leak at gasket C results in a slow shift to disengage rear auxiliary drive gearing; steady flow of air to atmosphere.

step1.para: Insert Valve ( Figure 9 and Figure 10). Any constant flow of air from the exhaust port of the cylinder cover usually indicates a faulty insert valve. Exhaust should occur ONLY BRIEFLY when the Splitter Control Button is moved FORWARD WHILE IN HIGH RANGE.
A faulty insert valve, leaking at the O-rings of valve O.D. or from inner seals will result in shift failure. Two indications of defective O-rings or seals are:

step2.para: CONSTANT AIR flowing from the exhaust port of the cylinder cover.
CONSTANT AIR flowing from Exhaust Port "E" of the control valve WHILE SPLITTER CONTROL BUTTON IS REARWARD (providing the control valve is operating properly).

svcsubproc.para: The three O-rings in position on the valve O.D. can be replaced. However, if an inner seal is damaged, the complete assembly MUST be replaced.
